channel.title: Ddwrt no "dir" command
channel.description:
I put ddwrt on my linksys router so I could get access to the antenna boosting option and I was playing around on the linux distro... What I cannot seem to figure out is a way to display directories content. In dos I would simply "dir" the directory and this seems to work on my webserver... However on this linux distro: BusyBox v1.9.1 (2008-03-19 20:24:03 CET) built-in shell (ash)
I simply get the error of:
[code]\u@\h:\w\$ dir -sh: dir: not found \u@\h:\w\$ [/code]
Also
[code]\u@\h:\w\$ ls / -sh: ls: not found [/code]
could this possibly be due to a bad install? or am I such a linux noob that a simpleminded windows user cannot grasp the knowledge of learning a new directory command!

item.title: Ddwrt no "dir" command
item.dc:creator: @postmanpat9 postmanpat9
item.description:
@postmanpat9 wrote:

did you run make install? Try /bin/busybox ls and see if that works.

http://busybox.net/downloads/BusyBox.html

Read full topic

item.title: Ddwrt no "dir" command
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It works fine for me:

[code]Trying 192.168.1.1…
Connected to travis.com.
Escape character is ‘^]’.

DD-WRT v24 std © 2008 NewMedia-NET GmbH
Release: 05/24/08 (SVN revision: 9526)

travis.com login: root
Password:

==========================================================

BusyBox v1.9.2 (2008-05-24 13:58:02 CEST) built-in shell (ash)
Enter ‘help’ for a list of built-in commands.

root@travis:~# ls
root@travis:~# help

Built-in commands:

    . : [ [[ alias bg break cd chdir command continue echo eval exec
    exit export false fg getopts hash help jobs kill let local pwd
    read readonly return set shift source test times trap true type
    ulimit umask unalias unset wait

root@travis:~# aoeu
-sh: aoeu: not found
root@travis:~# ls
root@travis:~# cd /bin/
root@travis:/bin# ls
ash df gzip mount rmdir umount
busybox dmesg hostname mount.cifs run-parts uname
cat echo ipkg mv sed usleep
chgrp egrep kill netstat sh vi
chmod false ln pidof sleep watch
chown fgrep login ping sync wc
cp getopt ls ps tar zcat
date grep mkdir pwd touch
dd gunzip more rm true
root@travis:/bin#[/code]

item.description:

I’m interested in this, what is the point of having it on your router?

I use it on my linksys wrtgl for receiving internet from another router wirelessly and have a wire connected to my xbox.

item.title: Ddwrt no "dir" command
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

COMMANDS

Currently defined functions include:

    [, [[, addgroup, adduser, adjtimex, ar, arp, arping, ash, awk, 
    basename, bbconfig, bbsh, bunzip2, busybox, bzcat, cal, cat, 
    catv, chattr, chcon, chgrp, chmod, chown, chpasswd, chpst, 
    chroot, chrt, chvt, cksum, clear, cmp, comm, cp, cpio, crond, 
    crontab, cryptpw, cut, date, dc, dd, deallocvt, delgroup, 
    deluser, devfsd, df, dhcprelay, diff, dirname, dmesg, dnsd, 
    dos2unix, dpkg, dpkg_deb, du, dumpkmap, dumpleases, e2fsck, echo, 
    ed, eject, env, envdir, envuidgid, ether_wake, expand, expr, 
    fakeidentd, false, fbset, fdflush, fdformat, fdisk, find, fold, 
    free, freeramdisk, fsck, fsck_minix, ftpget, ftpput, fuser, 
    getenforce, getopt, getsebool, getty, grep, gunzip, gzip, halt, 
    hdparm, head, hexdump, hostid, hostname, httpd, hwclock, id, 
    ifconfig, ifdown, ifup, inetd, init, insmod, install, ip, ipaddr, 
    ipcalc, ipcrm, ipcs, iplink, iproute, iprule, iptunnel, kill, 
    killall, killall5, klogd, lash, last, length, less, ln, 
    load_policy, loadfont, loadkmap, logger, login, logname, logread, 
    losetup, ls, lsattr, lsmod, lzmacat, makedevs, matchpathcon, 
    md5sum, mdev, mesg, microcom, mkdir, mke2fs, mkfifo, mkfs_minix, 
    mknod, mkswap, mktemp, modprobe, more, mount, mountpoint, mt, mv, 
    nameif, nc, netstat, nice, nmeter, nohup, nslookup, od, openvt, 
    passwd, patch, pgrep, pidof, ping, ping6, pivot_root, pkill, 
    poweroff, printenv, printf, ps, pscan, pwd, raidautorun, rdate, 
    readahead, readlink, readprofile, realpath, reboot, renice, 
    reset, resize, restorecon, rm, rmdir, rmmod, route, rpm, 
    rpm2cpio, run_parts, runcon, runlevel, runsv, runsvdir, rx, sed, 
    selinuxenabled, seq, setarch, setconsole, setenforce, setfiles, 
    setkeycodes, setlogcons, setsid, setuidgid, sha1sum, slattach, 
    sleep, softlimit, sort, split, start_stop_daemon, stat, strings, 
    stty, su, sulogin, sum, sv, svlogd, swapoff, swapon, switch_root, 
    sync, sysctl, syslogd, tail, tar, taskset, tcpsvd, tee, telnet, 
    telnetd, test, tftp, time, top, touch, tr, traceroute, true, tty, 
    ttysize, tune2fs, udhcpc, udhcpd, udpsvd, umount, uname, 
    uncompress, unexpand, uniq, unix2dos, unlzma, unzip, uptime, 
    usleep, uudecode, uuencode, vconfig, vi, vlock, watch, watchdog, 
    wc, wget, which, who, whoami, xargs, yes, zcat, zcip</blockquote>

They don’t have dir there, but they have ls.
